articles.headline: Now Departing: Airline Careers
articles.snippet: Many of the airline industry’s longtime workers have begun to look elsewhere to revive their interest in going to work.
articles.abstract: Many of the airline industry’s longtime workers have begun to look elsewhere to revive their interest in going to work.
articles.lead_paragraph: OCEANSIDE, N.Y. — Workers at many airlines have been forced to take huge pay cuts in recent years, and they have watched 100,000 or so of their colleagues lose their jobs.

articles.headline: Tyco to Pay $3 Billion to Settle Investor Lawsuits
articles.snippet: The settlement, described as the largest payment in such a suit, seeks to put to rest a famous corporate excess case.
articles.abstract: The settlement, described as the largest payment in such a suit, seeks to put to rest a famous corporate excess case.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tyco International, whose two top executives were imprisoned for fraud, has agreed to pay almost $3 billion to settle class-action lawsuits brought by investors, the company announced yesterday.

articles.headline: Poppy Fields Are Now a Front Line in Afghan War
articles.snippet: Until recently, U.S. officials admit, fighting drugs was considered a distraction from fighting terrorists.
articles.abstract: Until recently, U.S. officials admit, fighting drugs was considered a distraction from fighting terrorists.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a walled compound outside Kabul, two members of Colombia’s counternarcotics police force are trying to teach raw Afghan recruits how to wage close-quarters combat.

articles.headline: Proxy Fights More Muted, for Most Part
articles.snippet: Fireworks have so far been rare at shareholder meetings this year. But today’s meeting of shareholders of AMR may be an exception.
articles.abstract: Fireworks have so far been rare at shareholder meetings this year. But today’s meeting of shareholders of AMR may be an exception.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fireworks have so far been rare at annual shareholder meetings this year. With stock indexes near their record highs, investor anger, not surprisingly, has been muted.

articles.headline: It’s Not Just Honey
articles.snippet: Burt’s Bees makes simple products using plain ingredients, selling them in cheerful, tongue-in-cheek retro packages.
articles.abstract: Burt’s Bees makes simple products using plain ingredients, selling them in cheerful, tongue-in-cheek retro packages.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONE Friday last month, thousands of New York City commuters on their way home from work stopped to sample fruity-smelling hand lotions and macadamia body butter inside a big yellow tent next to Grand Central Terminal.

articles.headline: Sometimes, What’s Needed Is a Nudge
articles.snippet: In areas like health care and education, innovative people are starting to devise policies based on the economics of nudging.
articles.abstract: In areas like health care and education, innovative people are starting to devise policies based on the economics of nudging.
articles.lead_paragraph: I was walking through the intensive care unit of a San Francisco hospital earlier this year when I noticed a jarring sight. Most of the patients in the unit were sitting up in their beds. Some of them were gravely ill, drifting in and out of consciousness, but their mechanical beds were still propped up, much as the bed of an alert patient receiving visitors might be.

articles.headline: Thomson Adds Reuters in $17 Billion Bid to Be Giant
articles.snippet: The new company will compete with Bloomberg in selling data services and analytical and trading tools to Wall Street.
articles.abstract: The new company will compete with Bloomberg in selling data services and analytical and trading tools to Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO, May 15 — In the information age, content may be king. But the real power lies in what you can do with it.
